Award.AwardTitle: PaleoCore: A model for Developing Distributed Data Frameworks in SBE and EHR

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: A common scientific challenge is that of merging together results from independent research programs in order to conduct broad, synthetic analyses, as for example when astronomers focus on different segments of the night sky, geologists on specific times spans, and biologists on specific groups of organisms. In these cases, the answers to major scientific questions arise when the independent groups can successfully exchange and integrate their data into a comprehensive framework for analysis. Creating new, large-scale, next-generation data resources in the social, behavioral and economic sciences (SBE) and for education and human resources (EHR) too will require linking independent data sources into larger, coherent data structures. The PaleoCore initiative will create data standards and software tools to facilitate the aggregation of data into federated data networks. The project leverages data standards, and software solutions from other scientific disciplines to rapidly develop solutions relevant to SBE and EHR. The approach taken by the PaleoCore initiative is to start with a specific topic in SBE, human prehistory, and develop solutions that are broadly applicable to other scientific domains within SBE and EHR. Toward this aim the project has three main goals: 1) to develop and publish a data standard for prehistory, 2) to develop software tools that facilitate researchers' ability to record collected data directly into databases, especially geospatial databases, and 3) to develop a web portal that integrates individual project databases online into a federated network of data providers serving information to researchers, students and the general public. Through these objectives scientists in the SBE and EHR sciences will have a mechanism for broad-scale data integration, visualization, analysis and dissemination. This framework creates the foundation for answering big-picture questions beyond the reach of individual research projects and opens the door to new knowledge based on large, aggregated data sets.

Performance_Institution.Name: The University of Texas at Austin

POR.DRECONTENT:
A common scientific challenge is that of merging together results from independent research programs in order to address broader and more significant scientific questions that can't be addressed with information from one project alone. Each project may hold a piece of the puzzle but only by collaborating can the broader puzzle be solved. Research on human origins (including human paleontology and prehistoric archaeology) is a perfect example of this problem. Researchers working at individual field sites must find ways to integrate data in order to tackle the challenge of understanding the broader questions, trends and processes that shaped our evolution.

            The PaleoCore initiative addresses three critical aspects of the data integration problem, and provides a template for other areas of research in the social and behavioral sciences.  The program tackled three key challenges. The first was developing a data standard that allows information from different projects to be shared and combined effectively. This challenge was met primarily by modifying existing data standards and tailoring them to human origins research by providing examples, and documented best practices. The second challenge was developing a digital data collection toolkit that promoted a) fully digital data collection field methodology, b) the use of the data standard by providing useful data collection tools built around that standard and c) an integrated workflow that increased data reliability and makes it easier for research teams to collect and manage data collaboratively.  Finally, the tools were integrated with an online spatial data repository established at the Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC). This repository includes a web-based interface that allows research teams to collaboratively create, edit and share data online.

            The source code for the PaleoCore website is freely available to researchers, students and the general public through its GitHub repository.  The project is developed entirely around free open source software (FOSS) and can be used as a template for future spatial database initiatives in research, education or commercial applications.
